attributes.review:
the first six months of the Trump presidency have been a whirlwind of Russia-related news, with revelations about the Kremlinâ€™s attempt to sway the election and the Trump campaignâ€™s possible role in the effort surfacing nearly every day. But imagine for a moment a world in which the Russia scandal didnâ€™t exist. Pretend that Trump didnâ€™t fire FBI Director James Comey, or that Don Jr. never met with a Russian lawyer and a former Soviet spy promising dirt on Hillary Clinton. Forget that Michael Flynn and Paul Manafort had to register retroactively as foreign agents, or even that Trump said he wouldnâ€™t have hired Jeff Sessions if heâ€™d known the attorney general would recuse himself from the Russia probe.

What youâ€™re left with is still a remarkable amount of other administration scandalsâ€”from the State Departmentâ€™s stay at a Trump hotel to Jared Kushnerâ€™s disclosure problemsâ€”that would have been major news any other year, with any other president in the White House. Here are a few to remember.

The Emoluments Clause of the Constitution says the president cannot â€œwithout the consent of the Congress, accept of any present, emolument, office, or title, of any kind whatever, from any king, prince, or foreign state.â€ This means that many of Trumpâ€™s continued business dealingsâ€”he has refused to divest from his real estate companyâ€”could very well be illegal: For one, Trump has put his name on properties all over the worldâ€”from the Philippines to Saudi Arabiaâ€”and receives foreign money from his overseas holdings constantly.

Thereâ€™s also the issue of the Trump International Hotel in downtown Washington, D.C., which has become a popular destination for foreign diplomats. A week after the November election, about 100 foreign officials were invited to an event at the property, during which they toured the building and sipped champagne. While Trump promised before taking office that heâ€™d donate all profits earned from foreign governments to the U.S. Treasury, he doesnâ€™t appear to have kept that pledge. So far, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Turkey have all held events at the hotel, but thereâ€™s also the trickier matter of how to account for individuals linked to foreign governments. A Trump Organization pamphlet published in May said that â€œputting forth a policy that asks all guests to identify themselves would impede upon personal privacy and diminish the guest experience of our brand.â€

In January, the nonprofit group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) welcomed Trump to the White House by suing him on the grounds that he was already in violation of the Emoluments Clause. The Justice Department responded with a 70-page legal brief defending the presidentâ€™s conduct and calling for the suitâ€™s dismissal

.

During the 2016 presidential campaign, 15 women claimed to have been sexually assaulted by Trump, going on the record to accuse him of groping themâ€”in planes, offices, hotels, even golf and tennis tournaments. The then-presidential nominee vehemently denied any accounts of misconduct, and suggested the women werenâ€™t attractive enough to merit his attention. But in January, Summer Zeryos, a former â€œApprenticeâ€ contestant who had accused Trump of kissing her, grabbing her breast and thrusting his groin toward her in 2007, but whose accusation Trump had dismissed as â€œtotally made up nonsense,â€ sued Trump for defamation. Zervosâ€™ suit claims that Trumpâ€™s malicious response to her and othersâ€”he repeatedly called her and other women who came forward â€œliarsâ€â€”resulted in â€œthreats of violence, economic harm, and reputational damage.â€ In March, Trump claimed that as president, he should have immunity from Zeryosâ€™ suit. It will serve only to â€œdistract a president from his public duties to the detriment of not only the president and his office but also the Nation,â€ wrote his lawyer, Marc Kasowitz, in a filing. In July, Kawowitz filed a motion for dismissal. It hasnâ€™t yet been granted.

The first ladyâ€™s bio on the White House website, as first published in January, noted her modeling accolades and charitable causes, but also included what many sawas a blatant endorsement of her products. â€œMelania is also a successful entrepreneur,â€ the bio read. â€œIn April 2010, Melania Trump launched her own jewelry collection, â€˜Melaniaâ„¢ Timepieces & Jewelry,â€™ on QVC.â€ The episode was added to the growing evidence of blurred lines between business and public service in the Trump administration. Facing backlash, the White House quickly removed the QVC plug from the website

When Nordstrom announced it would stop selling Ivanka Trump's clothing line in February, Trump took to Twitter to defend his daughter. Later that week, not even three weeks after the Melania QVC debacle, presidential aide Kellyanne Conway delivered a ringingendorsement of the brand herself from the White House briefing room, urging Americans, â€œGo buy Ivankaâ€™s stuff.â€ The rules are clear on this: Executive branch employees canâ€™t use public office for private gain, to endorse any product or for the private gain of friends. The Office of Government Ethics wrote that â€œthere is strong reason to believeâ€ the action had violated the Standards of Conduct, and Conway was supposedly reprimanded for the mistake by Trump himselfâ€”but no disciplinary action was taken.
